articles.headline: Wells Fargo Workers Claim Retaliation for Playing by the Rules
articles.snippet: In two lawsuits seeking class-action status, workers say they were fired or demoted for acting ethically and falling short of unrealistic sales goals.
articles.abstract: In two lawsuits seeking class-action status, workers say they were fired or demoted for acting ethically and falling short of unrealistic sales goals.
articles.lead_paragraph: At least 5,300 Wells Fargo employees have been fired for ethics violations like setting up illicit accounts without customers’ knowledge to meet sales targets. Now there’s another group of aggrieved Wells Fargo workers: people who say they were fired or demoted for staying honest and falling short of sales goals they say were unrealistic.

articles.headline: Trump’s a Businessman. Where’s His Business Backing?
articles.snippet: Despite pushing proposals that sound like a corporate chieftain’s dream, the Republican nominee isn’t getting much love from his peers.
articles.abstract: Despite pushing proposals that sound like a corporate chieftain’s dream, the Republican nominee isn’t getting much love from his peers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Should it come as a surprise that not one chief executive among the Fortune 100 has donated money to Donald Trump’s campaign?

articles.headline: Golf Great Arnold Palmer Was Also a Pioneering Pitchman
articles.snippet: Mr. Palmer hawked nearly 50 products over a half-century and created the template for the modern entrepreneurial athlete.
articles.abstract: Mr. Palmer hawked nearly 50 products over a half-century and created the template for the modern entrepreneurial athlete.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a grainy black-and-white 1968 television commercial, Arnold Palmer steers a Mercury Monterey up to a golf course, nodding approvingly at the coupe’s smooth handling. A few years later, Mr. Palmer was driving up to another course, this time in color, in a flashy Cadillac El Dorado.

articles.headline: Kerr Putney, Charlotte Chief, Had Cause in His Life to Distrust Police
articles.snippet: Caught between defending his officers and regaining the trust of many who claim he has reacted badly to the fatal police shooting of a black man.
articles.abstract: Caught between defending his officers and regaining the trust of many who claim he has reacted badly to the fatal police shooting of a black man.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Kerr Putney, who 15 months ago was sworn in as Charlotte’s second black police chief, has spoken openly of his own lingering, lifelong distrust of the police.
articles.byline: By Richard Fausset, Alan Blinder and Yamiche Alcindor

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump Press Pointed Attacks in Debate
articles.snippet: In the first general-election debate, Mr. Trump criticized Mrs. Clinton on trade and her email practices, and she called him unfit to be commander in chief.
articles.abstract: In the first general-election debate, Mr. Trump criticized Mrs. Clinton on trade and her email practices, and she called him unfit to be commander in chief.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a relentlessly antagonistic debate, Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton clashed over trade, the Iraq war, his refusal to release his tax returns and her use of a private email server, with Mr. Trump frequently showing impatience and political inexperience as Mrs. Clinton pushed him to defend his past denigration of women and President Obama.
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: How Hillary Clinton Went From Hesitant to Scorching
articles.snippet: Mrs. Clinton, with some help from the moderator, Lester Holt, found her footing during the second half and attacked Mr. Trump on his treatment of women.
articles.abstract: Mrs. Clinton, with some help from the moderator, Lester Holt, found her footing during the second half and attacked Mr. Trump on his treatment of women.
articles.lead_paragraph: It started with a mystifying missed opportunity on race. It ended with a piercing attack on gender.
articles.byline: By Michael Barbaro and Matt Flegenheimer

articles.headline: What Can Mexico Do About Trump?
articles.snippet: Few, if any, countries would be as vulnerable to a Trump presidency as Mexico, but its minister of the economy says his country “must not overreact to campaign rhetoric.”
articles.abstract: Few, if any, countries would be as vulnerable to a Trump presidency as Mexico, but its minister of the economy says his country “must not overreact to campaign rhetoric.”
articles.lead_paragraph: When Ildefonso Guajardo Villarreal, the Mexican secretary of the economy, came to talk to me last week about trade and the American elections, I didn’t expect him to drag up the old spat between Mexico and the United States over trucks.

articles.headline: After a Disappointing Debate, Donald Trump Goes on the Attack
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump lashed out at the debate moderator, complained about his microphone and threatened to make Bill Clinton’s marital infidelity a campaign issue in a TV appearance Tuesday.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump lashed out at the debate moderator, complained about his microphone and threatened to make Bill Clinton’s marital infidelity a campaign issue in a TV appearance Tuesday.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump lashed out on Tuesday in the aftermath of a disappointing first debate with Hillary Clinton, scolding the moderator, criticizing a beauty pageant winner for her physique and raising the prospect of an all-out attack on Bill Clinton’s marital infidelities in the final stretch of the campaign.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Nick Corasaniti

articles.headline: Does Donald Trump Pay Taxes? Here’s What We Know
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump’s refusal to release his tax returns allowed Hillary Clinton to suggest at the debate that perhaps he has not paid income taxes.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump’s refusal to release his tax returns allowed Hillary Clinton to suggest at the debate that perhaps he has not paid income taxes.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton had been waiting for this one: a line of questioning about Donald J. Trump’s refusal to release his income tax returns.
articles.byline: By Steve Eder and Patricia Cohen
